title: Forces in Action: Comparing Effects and Real-Life Applications
subject: Science

questions.question: A child pulls a toy car along a rough carpet. Which force opposes the motion of the car?
questions.explanation: Frictional force acts between the car’s wheels and the carpet, opposing its motion and making it harder to pull.

questions.question: Why can astronauts jump higher on the Moon than on Earth?
options: Because the Moon has no gravity
Because gravitational force is weaker on the Moon
Because there is more friction on the Moon
questions.explanation: The Moon’s gravitational force is about 1/6th of Earth’s, so astronauts weigh less and can jump higher with the same effort.

questions.question: Which of the following uses elastic spring force?
questions.explanation: When a basketball hits the ground, it deforms slightly and then springs back due to elastic spring force, causing it to bounce.

questions.question: Applying wax to skis helps a skier go faster. Why?
options: It reduces friction between the ski and snow
questions.explanation: Wax creates a smoother surface, reducing friction between the ski and snow, allowing faster movement.

questions.question: Which statement is TRUE about weight?
options: Weight is the same on Earth and the Moon
Weight depends only on the object’s volume
Weight is caused by gravitational force
Weight does not change with location
questions.explanation: Weight is the force of gravity acting on an object’s mass. It changes depending on the strength of gravity (e.g., less on the Moon).

questions.question: What happens when you add oil to the hinges of a squeaky door?
options: Friction increases, making it harder to open
Friction decreases, making it easier to open
questions.explanation: Oil acts as a lubricant, reducing friction between moving parts, so the door opens more smoothly.

questions.question: Which object demonstrates that a force can change the shape of an object?
options: A ball rolling down a hill
A book resting on a table
A leaf falling from a tree
questions.explanation: Stretching a rubber band changes its shape due to the applied force. When released, elastic spring force returns it to original shape.

questions.question: Two identical boxes are pushed—one on ice, one on concrete. Which requires more force to start moving?
questions.explanation: Concrete has more friction than ice, so more force is needed to overcome friction and start the box moving.

questions.question: Which of the following shows that forces act in pairs?
options: Pushing a wall and feeling it push back
An apple falling from a tree
A spring returning to its shape
questions.explanation: When you push a wall, you feel it pushing back on you—this illustrates Newton’s third law: forces always occur in equal and opposite pairs.

questions.question: Friction is useful when:
options: Sliding down a metal slide quickly
Writing with a pencil on paper
questions.explanation: Friction between the pencil tip and paper allows graphite to leave marks—without friction, writing would be impossible.
